chapter.title: Adding Flavor to Manager with Salt
chapter.subtitle: A Technical Preview

sect1.title: Introducing Salt
sect1.para: The addition of Salt to &susemgr; 3 fulfils customer demands by providing the latest in configuration management and includes a more consistent systems management framework.
In this chapter you will learn how to setup and configure your VM's created in the previous sections for use with the new Salt framework. In this section of the guide you will:

listitem.para: Configure your &sle; 12 client as the Salt-minion
Accept the Salt-minion key using the &susemgr; WebGUI
Use Salt to manage your client

note.title: Early Steps
note.para: This section assumes you have completed all earlier steps in this guide. Although you do not need to complete the chapter: Preparing and Registering Clients. It is recommended that you follow and execute the steps in order as this will provide your client with software sources and updates.

sect1.title: &susemgr; as the Salt-master
sect1.para: Once &susemgr; has been installed and setup, by default it is configured as a fully functional Salt-master. In the rest of this chapter &susemgr; will be referred to the Salt-master.

para.emphasis: When you are testing with the early technical preview a configuration file change is necessary to ensure your client can connect to the Salt-master

sect1.para: The following procedure will walk you through adding the technical preview configuration file change on the Salt-master

step.para: On the Salt-master (&susemgr; Server) as root browse to the /etc/salt directory and enter the following commands.
step.screen: salt-master:~ # cd /etc/salt salt-master: /etc/salt # ls master master.d pki roster salt-master: /etc/salt # vi master

step.para: Search for the #max_event_size: parameter and change its value to 6000000. When you are finished, uncomment the parameter then save and quit vi.
step.screen: # Passing very large events can cause the minion to consume large amounts of # memory. This value tunes the maximum size of a message allowed onto the # master event bus. The value is expressed in bytes. max_event_size: 6000000

note.title: Why change the max_event_size?
note.para: Currently when the Salt-master requests Grains (various information about a client: hardware, software, etc.) the list size is larger than the default value so the request times out. Changing this to a higher value enables to client to connect despite grain size. The number of packages installed effects this the most currently.

step.para: Once you have set the max_event_size you need to restart the Salt-master.

sect1.para: This concludes configuration of the Salt-master. The next section will guide you through configuration of the salt-minion.

sect1.title: Salt-minion Setup and Configuration
sect1.para: This section covers setup of Salt on the client.
Unlike the Salt-master clients do not have Salt installed by default. Therefore you must install the required packages. In this section you will:

listitem.para: Download the &susemgr; 3 ISO on the client
Add the &susemgr; 3 ISO as an ISO repository on the client
Change the event_max_size value on the client

procedure.title: Installing Salt-minion Packages on the Client

step.para: On your client system point your browser to: SUSE-Manager-Server-3.0-DVD-x86_64.iso. Download the DVD 1 image and mount it as an ISO repository. See also: &susemgr; 3 Installation as an Add-on.

para.emphasis: Do not install the full &susemgr; 3 pattern. This will install a &susemgr; server instance on your client. You only need the Salt-minion packages. This process should be automated for release.

step.para: Open the YaST Software Management tool. In the search field enter salt and press Enter. Select the Salt-minion package then click Accept to continue.

sect1.para: This concludes the salt-minion configuration section. The next part of this guide will cover acceptance of minions for management via the WebGUI.

sect1.title: Accepting Minions for Management
sect1.para: In this section you will accept minions using the &susemgr; WebGUI.

step.para: To get started open your browser and point it to your &susemgr; Server address and log in.
Select the Systems tab then Minions from the sidebar.
On the All Minions page you can see a list of Pending and Rejected minions.
The minion you configured in the previous section should be listed under the Pending column.
To accept the minion for management click the Check button.
Confirm your minion was added by going to the Systems tab. Your new minion is now ready for management by &susemgr; 3.
